markdownRemark.html:
Info about sequence databases

Sequence databases

A list of the major sequence databases today

  • Genbank: maintained by NCBI
  • The European Nucletide Archive (ENA): maintained by EMBL-EBI.
  • The DNA Data Bank of Japan (DDBJ) These three data bases exchange information every day so a lot of the data exists in all three databases.

Genebank

GeneBank Flat File: Standard format for Genebank entries. Starts with a header with information about the sequence. The header includes

  • Accession: an unique sequence id
  • Version: accession nr + version
  • Source: Species
  • Organism: whole taxification
  • Reference
  • Authors, title, journal

After the header comes the features-section of the GeneBank Flat File. The features section has two columns, one with keys like source and CDS (coding sequence) and one with the annotations to the sequence (i.e. the translated sequence in polypeptides).

The last part of the file consists of the origin-section. It contains actual nucleotide sequence.

Sequence similariy search

Similariy is a quanitity (15% or 30%) and homology is a boolean/inference.

When searching for distant relationships, it's good to seach protein sequence databases. Then it's possible to identify sequences that share ancestors >= 1 billion years ago (longest is over 2.5 billion years). For non-coding DNA sequences, it's hard to go back in time more than 200 million years. Protein coding sequences can go back 600 million years.

Basic Local Alignment Search Tool (BLAST)

The most popular programs f√∂r finding homologous sequences.

  • BLASTP: amino acid search in protein DB.
  • BLASTN: nucleotide search in nucleotide DB.
  • BLASTX: protein sequence generated from translation of nucleotide (in all 6 frames) in a protein DB.
  • TBLASTN: protein sequence in a DB with other nucleotide sequences translated in all 6 frames.
  • TBLASTX: same input as BLASTX but in a DB with other nucleotide sequences also translated in all 6 frames.

The search result includes an E-value which tells the probability of find this match by pure chance.

Factors to think about when finding a match:

  • Overall alignment
  • Gene duplications
  • Distance between species
  • Degree of protein conservation
  • Is it part of a metabolic pathway?
